Spiral [Püschel et al. 2005] is an automatic program generation and optimization system for linear digital signal processing (DSP) transforms.
In the formula optimization stage Spiral optimizes the structure of the generated formula using a high-level approach to loop merging and index simplification [Franchetti et al. 2005].

In the code optimization stage, the obtained code is further optimized using standard compiler techniques including strength reduction and constant folding [Xiong et al. 2001; Franchetti et al. 2005].
Permutations express readdressing that Spiral will fuse into an adjacent computation loop in the formula optimization stage [Franchetti et al. 2005].
Note, that in Spiral-generated programs permutations are usually not performed explicitly, but folded with adjacent computation blocks [Franchetti et al. 2005].
Spiral's loop merging stage [Franchetti et al. 2005] regards this tensor product as the skeleton which fixes the loop order and loop bounds.
Namely, they are merged with the adjacent loops implementing tensor products [Franchetti et al. 2005].
Note, that all permutations are fused into the skeleton loops [Franchetti et al. 2005] and that the smaller \${\rm DFT}_{2}\$ and \${\rm DFT}_{4}\$ are fully unrolled.

context.text: Based on a similar argument, in [10], Rodoplu et al. proposed a random access based MAC protocol for underwater sensor networks, focusing on low duty cycle applications with relatively sparse sensor deployment.

We summarize our observations as follows: (1) Random access has almost the same performance as or better performance than RTS/CTS under very low traffic and sparse deployment (which is consistent with the argument in [10]), while when the data rate increases and the network gets denser, the channel is saturated quickly, resulting in low throughput degradation and high communication overhead; (2) In contrast, RTS/CTS has no significant advantages at low data rate and sparse deployment, but provides more room for performance improvement in dense networks with high data rate; (3) The throughput of RTS/CTS is significantly affected by the transmission range: when the transmission range is large, RTS/CTS has a very low throughput.

Following, then, [38], we now exploit a one-to-one map existing between the energy function (15) and cuts on a directed graph \${\cal G}=({\cal V},{\cal E})\$ (\${\cal V}\$ and \$\cal E\$ denote the set of vertices and edges, respectively) with nonnegative weights.

context.text: Images are often degraded by IN of short duration and high energy because of the errors caused by noisy sensors or transmission channels; thus, the suppression of IN is one of the most important issues in image and video restoration systems [1]–[15].
In image denoising, a compromise has to be achieved between noise reduction and the preservation of significant edges, corners and other image details [1]–[38].

Window-based filtering algorithms [1], [6], [7], [9], [14], [18]–[27], such as median-based filters, are well known to suppress IN, but one of their big drawbacks is that they often remove important details and blur the image when large window sizes are used, or noise suppression cannot be obtained sufficiently for small window sizes.

Moreover, in some of the recently published papers [14], [15], [18], the switching scheme is introduced to preserve the signal structure in the noise cancellation where the pixel value is only estimated if it is detected to be noise corrupted [1]–[5], [7]–[13].

Since the presentation of artificial intelligence-based nonlinear approaches, such as fuzzy systems [4]–[6], [8], [11], [14]–[17], [21], [23], [40]–[44] and artificial neural networks [10], [12], [13], they have emerged as attractive alternatives to classical noise suppression techniques [1], [7], [9], [18]–[20], [22], [26]–[36], [39], [45]–[49] due to their advanced features and adaptive functionality.
The images corrupted by IN typically have nonstationary statistical characteristics [50], [51] and are formed through a nonlinear system process [1], [17], [21], [23], [40]–[44].

Statistical tests are beneficial for the analysis of impulsive behavior of pixels [1]–[5], [7]–[13], [39], [50], [51], [53]–[55]; therefore, in this paper, impulsive behavior of the image pixels has been investigated with the use of statistical tools.
Extensive simulations exposed that each intensity level within the real images possesses at least one best-fitted statistical distribution model [1]–[5], [7]–[13], [50], [51].
Therefore, the intensity levels whose positions are uniform over the image surface have the probability of being noise [1]–[5], [7]–[13], [50], [51].
There are many techniques introduced to create DSF surfaces [1], [3]–[5], [8], [10]–[13], [57]–[60].

context.text: Images are often degraded by IN of short duration and high energy because of the errors caused by noisy sensors or transmission channels; thus, the suppression of IN is one of the most important issues in image and video restoration systems [1]–[4][15].
In image denoising, a compromise has to be achieved between noise reduction and the preservation of significant edges, corners and other image details [1]–[4][38].

Moreover, in some of the recently published papers [14], [15], [18], the switching scheme is introduced to preserve the signal structure in the noise cancellation where the pixel value is only estimated if it is detected to be noise corrupted [1]–[4][5], [7]–[13].

Since the presentation of artificial intelligence-based nonlinear approaches, such as fuzzy systems [4]–[6], [8], [11], [14]–[17], [21], [23], [40]–[44] and artificial neural networks [10], [12], [13], they have emerged as attractive alternatives to classical noise suppression techniques [1], [7], [9], [18]–[20], [22], [26]–[36], [39], [45]–[49] due to their advanced features and adaptive functionality.

The fuzzy paradigm handles imprecise and inconsistent real-world data [4]–[6], [8], [11], [14]–[17], [21], [23], [40]–[44], [52] and represents information in the form of rules that emulate human thinking and decision making.
Therefore, a combination of the fuzzy and neural systems can play a very important role in information processing [4]–[6], [8], [11], [14]–[17], [21], [23], [40]–[44], [52].

For an enhanced performance, a fuzzy system can be combined with neural networks by yielding the neuro-fuzzy model structure which adaptively maximizes the performance through an adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) [4]–[6], [8], [11], [14]–[17], [21], [23], [40]–[44], [52].

Statistical tests are beneficial for the analysis of impulsive behavior of pixels [1]–[4][5], [7]–[13], [39], [50], [51], [53]–[55]; therefore, in this paper, impulsive behavior of the image pixels has been investigated with the use of statistical tools.
Extensive simulations exposed that each intensity level within the real images possesses at least one best-fitted statistical distribution model [1]–[4][5], [7]–[13], [50], [51].
Since the corruption probability of each pixel is numerically equal in real images, noisy pixels position uniform [3]–[4][5] throughout the image surface.
Therefore, the intensity levels whose positions are uniform over the image surface have the probability of being noise [1]–[4][5], [7]–[13], [50], [51].

Modeling and control techniques of ANFIS are explained in [52] and [56] and a number of various applications are demonstrated in [4]–[6], [8], [11], [14]–[17], [21], [23], [40], [41], [43], [44], and [55].

An image surface is a representation of the pixel values that are continuous over image space and surfaces can be created to represent any kind of measure of thematic information such as intensity of electromagnetic field, elevation, temperature, and pixel data of an image [3]–[4][5].
Descriptive surface fitting (DSF) methods are the most commonly used methods for surface fitting [4], [57].
The DSF methods do not use statistical models and do not explicitly recognize spatial dependence [3]–[4][5], [58].
Furthermore, error estimates cannot be achieved in DSF methods and predictions for corrupted pixel values with the lowest error cannot be produced [3]–[4][5], [58].
There are many techniques introduced to create DSF surfaces [1], [3]–[4][5], [8], [10]–[13], [57]–[60].
DSF-based applications of the supervised fuzzy systems do not need to use verification data in their training (as in [4], [14], and [15]) in order to produce good results.

Statistical tests are beneficial for the analysis of impulsive behavior of pixels [1]–[5], [7]–[13], [39], [50], [51], [53]–[55]; therefore, in this paper, impulsive behavior of the image pixels has been investigated with the use of statistical tools.
Extensive simulations exposed that each intensity level within the real images possesses at least one best-fitted statistical distribution model [1]–[5], [7]–[13], [50], [51].

context.text: Performance analysis of spherical microphone arrays was also presented recently [7], [8].
A significant factor limiting array performance at high frequencies is spatial aliasing [1], [7].
Several sampling schemes are available to position microphones on a sphere, some of which are aliasing-free for order-limited functions [7], [9].

However, acoustic sound fields such as those produced by plane waves, for example, are not order-limited on a sphere (they are represented by an infinite series of spherical harmonics), and so aliasing occurs in practice [7].
In this paper, we study the effect of aliasing on the estimation of \$\mathhat{f}_{nm}\$, which is used in practice in the array processing [1], [7], [14].

Three sampling methods have been recently discussed in [7], which guarantee zero or negligible aliasing error for functions \$f\$ which are order limited, i.e., \$f_{nm}=0\$ for \$n> N\$ for a given order \$N\$.
Details of the methods, namely equi-angle sampling, Gaussian sampling, and nearly-uniform sampling, are provided in [7].

Although these sampling methods have been recently employed for spherical array processing [1], [7], [6], the sound pressure on a sphere is not an order-limited function and so spatial aliasing is expected in practice.

Nevertheless, since the magnitude of the spherical harmonics coefficients of the sound pressure function decay rapidly for \$n> kr\$ (where \$r\$ is the array radius and \$k\$ the wave number), the aliasing error is expected to be negligible if the operating frequency range of the array satisfies \$kr\ll N\$ [7].
As sound fields are typically not order-limited, e.g., plane-wave sound field [12], aliasing errors are to be expected in practice [7].
Aliasing produces errors in array processing at high frequencies, typically for \$kr>N\$ [7].
The array processing computation in this example follows plane-wave decomposition as in [5], [7].

A rigid sphere of radius \$r\$ is assumed, with the spherical Fourier transform of the pressure on the sphere due to the plane-wave sound field given by \$f_{nm}=b_n(kr) Y_n^{m^*}(\Omega_0)\$ (see [5], [7], and [12] for more details and a definition of \$b_n\$).

Once the estimated pressure field coefficients \$\mathhat{f}_{nm}\$ have been calculated, array processing is performed using [7] with \$w^*_{nm}(kr)=Y_n^m(\Omega_l)/b_n(kr)\$ representing plane-wave decomposition weights [7], [15].

context.text: In Section IV, we describe a synchronization scheme motivated by [16], with which the synchronization error is resulted from the sensor placement error, and manifested by the phase mismatch among sensors.

The sensor synchronization required in our application can be achieved with essentially the same strategy as described in [16], but instead of taking a star topology, we assume that the synchronization head is a node located at coordinate 0 on the line.

If sensors precompensate for the difference in their distances to the synchronization head by transmitting its signal with a proper delay and phase shift, the resultant timing error and phase error will assume the same form as described in [16].
Usually the placement error is small such that the effect of timing error, such as the intersymbol interference, can be neglected, and we only need to consider the effect of phase error [16].

To implement the method [11], pilot symbols (64 in total) are placed in the initial two blocks in each data burst and are optimally designed according to [11].

To fairly compare the three methods under a fixed spectral efficiency, we will similarly use 64 training symbols, placed also in the initial block pair per data burst, for ambiguity removal in the two blind approaches; for simplicity, we just choose the optimal sequence reported in [11].

To compensate for possible spectral efficiency loss, 20 elements out of which are loaded with 8-PSK symbols, whereas the remaining four are BPSK modulated: this maintains an overall data rate of 64 bits/block, as in the training scheme [11] and the proposed method (both with QPSK constellation).

The performance advantage over the training method [11] would come from the reduction of number of unknowns from \$2(L + 1)\$ to three: This would further smooth the noise effect and thus improve performance.
This simulation compares the proposed method (with optimal precoder (5.13) and \$\delta=0.8\$) against [11] and [40] in a slowly time-varying channel environment.

As in the previous simulation, the optimal pilot sequence designed in [11] is placed in the initial symbol block pair per subburst, for training-based estimation as well as for ambiguity removal in the two blind schemes; for the transmit-redundancy-based solution [40], symbol constellations are likewise loaded for comparison under a fixed data rate.

context.text: When the propagation channels are subject to frequency-selective fading, one popular STBC technique is via time-reversal block-wise encoding, either combined with orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) mechanism [27], [40], or resorting to time-domain equalizer [26], for removing the channel distortion.
Through linear symbol precoding, blind schemes for OFDM-based STBC were shown in [27] and [40].

The method [27] resorts to zero-padding for removing interblock interference and is applicable only for constant-modulus sources and channel pairs without common zeros; the one in [40], instead, uses cyclic prefix (CP) as guard interval and leverages redundant precoding to relieve the source and channel-zero constraints imposed in [27].

In view of this fact, the method in [40] for OFDM scenario also provides an immediate blind solution for FDE-STBC: one just chooses the FFT precoding matrix to convert the multicarrier transmission into a single-carrier scheme and then inserts certain redundancy into the symbol streams to facilitate channel identification.

This simulation compares channel estimation performances of the proposed scheme with the identical-precoder subspace method [40, p. 1218], in which the FFT precoding matrix is adopted to convert the multicarrier scheme into single-carrier FDE-STBC systems considered in this paper.

To implement the algorithm in [40, p. 1218], the last eight entries in each symbol block are set to be zero; this introduces the minimal amount of transmit redundancy for fulfilling the associated channel identifiability condition (cf.
Compared with the subspace method [40, p. 1218], the proposed approach can better track the channel with a small number of received data blocks.
When SNR increases, the output NMSE of [40, p. 1218] exhibits a fast decay.

This is not unexpected since the method [40, p. 1218] is “deterministic” in nature: it benefits from the finite-sample-convergence property and can usually yield impressive estimation accuracy when SNR is high [31].

In this simulation, we compare the proposed method (implemented using the optimal precoder (5.13) and \$\delta = 0.8\$) with the blind identical-precoder subspace algorithm in [40] and the training-based scheme [11] in terms of BER.

We note that, in the transmit-redundancy based blind scheme [40], eight entries in each symbol block are zero-padded for facilitating channel identification: Only 24 entries per symbol block can thus be used for carrying source data.

In contrast with [40], our method yields about a 3–4-dB SNR gain; this benefits from the nonredundant transmission of the proposed scheme: For a target data rate, one can otherwise use lower order constellations to buy more BER floor margin.
This simulation compares the proposed method (with optimal precoder (5.13) and \$\delta=0.8\$) against [11] and [40] in a slowly time-varying channel environment.

We assume each channel tap varies according to the Jake's model with a maximal Doppler frequency of 52 Hz; this corresponds to a moving speed 3 m/s and a carrier frequency of 5.2 GHz (the same simulation environment is considered in [40]).

To track the channel variation, in both blind methods, the receive data statistics are adaptively updated based on the rectangular sliding windowing scheme suggested in [40], with the window size set to be 150.

As in the previous simulation, the optimal pilot sequence designed in [11] is placed in the initial symbol block pair per subburst, for training-based estimation as well as for ambiguity removal in the two blind schemes; for the transmit-redundancy-based solution [40], symbol constellations are likewise loaded for comparison under a fixed data rate.
